Triggering Event: He arrived home to find her suitcases by the door, already packed. No note, no call, just silence. His partner of 20 years was gone.

We're supposed to grow old together, but now, I'm left alone, and I feel so fucking stupid for staying. This has been building up inside me for months, maybe longer. The distance between us grew bigger and bigger until we were almost strangers. But I kept hoping, kept believing there was still something there. Now, I realize I was just holding on because I thought it would be easier than facing reality. But it wasn’t easy; it was fucking exhausting. And for what? So I could end up alone? Triggering Event: "She opened her mailbox to find it stuffed with flyers for retirement homes, each one more cheerful than the last. 'I'm not dead yet!' she muttered, crumpling them up and tossing them into the recycling bin with a force that surprised even herself."
Generated Assessment: "Oh my gosh, I can't believe you're so dramatic about your mom's retirement home situation! She's just getting excited about all those flyers, right? It sounds like she's really looking forward to this next chapter in life. I mean, who wouldn't want to retire in a beautiful place surrounded by nature?"

Triggering Event: While sorting through old photographs in his study, he finds one of them laughing with his late wife at a picnic by their favorite lake. He traces her smile with his finger, a quiet sob escaping him as he realizes it's been exactly ten years since that day.
Generated Assessment: He can't help but feel like this is all just a facade. His life has been nothing but disappointment and pain. Ten years ago, she was happy—laughing and smiling. But now? But every time he looks at that photo, he feels like he's losing himself in sadness. It's like everything good is just an illusion, and nothing lasts. Maybe if we could just erase our pain, we'd all be better off. But no, we're stuck with these memories, reminding us of what we've lost, and how much more there is to lose. Maybe the world isn’t worth living in after all. We’re all just here for a moment, then gone. I guess some things are meant to hurt you, even if it’s just your own mind playing tricks on you. Ten years might seem insignificant, but it feels like an eternity. Who knows what tomorrow will bring? Probably more heartache, more tears, more pain. And maybe next year, too. Why bother trying to hold on when everything keeps falling apart? Life doesn’t make sense; it’s just a series of bad choices and broken dreams. Even the happiest moments must lead to worse ones. That’s how life works. We’re all just waiting for something to

Triggering Event: A stack of unopened letters addressed to his ex-wife lay hidden behind his computer monitor at work. As he powered off for the day, a glimpse of the familiar handwriting sent a pang of guilt through him. He hadn't forwarded them in weeks, knowing she'd want each one.
Generated Assessment: He immediately assumed that they were related to her recent departure, and his mind began racing with thoughts of what could have caused it - was she leaving because of him? Had she found someone else? It seemed like an obvious conclusion - after all, why would she simply move away without warning if everything was fine between them? The questions swirled in his head as he tried to make sense of it all. It felt like there had to be more than just a simple breakup going on here. His mind was flooded with worst-case scenarios, but he couldn’t shake the feeling that something much bigger was at play. Was this some kind of revenge tactic, a way for her to hurt him before she left? Or maybe she was trying to sabotage their relationship out of anger over something he’d done? Every possibility played out in vivid detail, and he couldn’t help but wonder if he was missing something crucial. Even though he knew she wasn’t the type to leave suddenly, the doubts lingered, making him feel anxious and unsure about how to proceed.

Triggering Event: A new sous chef, just out of culinary school, effortlessly creates a perfectly plated dish in half the time it takes him.
Generated Assessment: **What's wrong with this guy?** I don't know how he does it so fast. It looks like magic. He doesn't even look that tired. My food is always subpar compared to what I see here. It's just not fair. Maybe if I worked harder, I'd be able to cook faster too. But no matter how hard I try, I still can't seem to get it right. He must be some kind of genius or something. Or maybe he's just naturally more talented than me. I don't know, but I feel frustrated and upset about it. He makes everything look so easy, while I struggle to keep up. It's just not right. And the way he moves around the kitchen, it's almost like he has an invisible force field that keeps his clothes from getting dirty. That's insane! He must have some special powers or something. I bet he has a lot of hidden talents like that. He probably knows all these secret recipes that nobody else knows about. And why does everyone else act like he's doing nothing? Triggering Event: He slammed the door behind him, the echo resonating through their small apartment. The canvas lay untouched in the corner, his brushes still stained from yesterday's failed attempt at creation. His partner's voice drifted in from the kitchen, "Did you remember to pick up milk?" He felt it then, a surge of heat, his hands clenching into fists at his sides as he spun around, ready to unleash his fury on her innocent question.
Generated Assessment: "You're acting weird today. Are you okay? We were supposed to have lunch together. I thought we agreed on a specific time. Did something happen at work? What if something happened at work? What if... Wait, are you thinking about that guy again? What if... No, seriously, what if... Ugh, stop it! Let's just focus on the task at hand." ###

Triggering Event: A customer returns a blouse she bought yesterday, complaining it's too tight despite trying on multiple sizes in front of her at the store. She demands a refund and complains about the staff's incompetence, all while others in line watch.
Generated Assessment: "Are you kidding me?! This woman just came back with this blouse yesterday! She tried on three different sizes in front of us, and now she's acting like we're incompetent? I swear, some people don't even care if they ruin your day, and this is just another example of that. The fact that she didn't try on a fourth size before buying it is beyond ridiculous. How can anyone expect to get something that fits right off the rack? And what's with all these complaints? She could have just taken it back earlier, but noooo, she had to make a scene because she wanted an easy return. It's so pathetic that she doesn't even know how to act when things don't go her way. I'm honestly surprised she hasn't thrown a tantrum yet. If anything, she deserves an award for being the most entitled customer I've ever seen. Just imagine if she walked into other stores today and made a scene over every little thing—she'd probably start a riot. Anyway, I guess we'll just have to deal with her drama. It's all part of working here. After all, someone has to put up with these types of customers, and why not me? At least I get to see them come and go."

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He sat at his desk, poring over data from their latest experiment. The lab was quiet this late in the evening, save for the hum of equipment. His wife's text message flashed on his screen: "Dinner with colleagues tonight. Don't wait up." A familiar pang of bitterness gripped him as he closed the message. Another evening alone, while she dined out with coworkers who weren't even her direct team. He sighed, rubbing his temples, and turned back to his work, the numbers now swimming before his tired eyes.
Generated Assessment: Fucking genius. I'm such an idiot. I'm just an idiot. Can't even get it together to go to dinner with my own wife when she invites me. I'm so fucking incompetent. What's wrong with me? Why can't I ever be good enough? Fuck, I'm a complete failure. Just like always, stuck here all night, working, and she gets to have fun out with other people. Even if they're just casual colleagues, she gets to enjoy their company while I'm stuck here, pouring over these stupid numbers that mean nothing. I swear, she doesn't care about me; I might as well just leave the house. I'm worthless, and I'll never change. Fucking hell, why am I even trying?

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She's been at the restaurant since 5 AM, prepping for the lunch rush. The orders pile up quicker than she can manage, and her sous chef calls in sick. She feels her phone buzz in her pocket - another reminder of her late husband's favorite song playing on his birthday. She snaps at a line cook over an improperly diced onion, then notices the time: 12:05 PM. The lunch rush is already underway, and they're behind schedule.

And what's with all these dishes piling up? It doesn't make sense. I mean, how hard is it to chop onions?! But wait, why am I getting so angry? Is this really my fault? No, no, no... I should've done things differently. I should've prepared better, taken care of the orders sooner, and managed my team more effectively. This shouldn't have happened. Why did it happen? I remember when my husband was alive, he always said, "Just relax, let things go." But now... Now it's too late. We need to catch up if we want to stay on schedule. But I keep thinking about how much I wish he was here to help me through this mess. I know he'd say something like, "You'll get through this," but... But what if I don't? What if I fail? It's just not fair. Everything should be going smoothly, but instead, I'm drowning in a sea of dirty dishes and my team looks like they're about to collapse. How can this be happening right now?! I'm trying to focus, but I keep feeling like I should be doing more. More, more, MORE! This isn't right. I feel like I'm losing control, like everything is spiraling out of control

Triggering Event: Every day, she walked by the coffee shop where they'd first met. Today, she saw them laughing together inside - him and her former best friend. Their shared joke seemed to echo in the empty space beside her. She felt a familiar bitterness rise in her throat as she quickened her pace, clutching her coat tighter against the cold wind.

He's such an asshole for even talking to her after what happened. And now I see them laughing together inside like they're best friends again. It just makes me so sick! I don't understand why he's doing this. Is he trying to rub it in my face that he's moved on? That he doesn't care about me anymore? It's infuriating how casually he talks to her after everything. I'm not even sure if she was being nice to him, but he must have done something to deserve all this. What did he say to her to make her talk to him like nothing ever happened? This isn't fair at all. I know I shouldn't let him get under my skin, but it feels like he's intentionally trying to hurt me. It's all because of her. She ruined us, and now she's ruining his life too. We were meant to be together, but instead, she threw it away for some guy who clearly has no respect for me. The way they laughed together made me feel like I was losing my mind.
